pullsbody:
Fixes #72


As of January 1 2019, Mozilla requires that all GitHub projects include this [CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md](https://github.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) file in the project root. The file has two parts:

1. Required Text - All text under the headings *Community Participation Guidelines and How to Report*, are required, and should not be altered.
2. Optional Text - The Project Specific Etiquette heading provides a space to speak more specifically about ways people can work effectively and inclusively together. Some examples of those can be found on the [Firefox Debugger](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) project, and [Common Voice](https://github.com/mozilla/voice-web/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). (The optional part is commented out in the [raw template file](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), and will not be visible until you modify and uncomment that part.)

If you have any questions about this file, or Code of Conduct policies and procedures, please see [Mozilla-GitHub-Standards](https://wiki.mozilla.org/GitHub/Repository_Requirements) or email Mozilla-GitHub-Standards+CoC@mozilla.com.

_(Message COC002)_
pull_repo_desc: Create, list, and load GitHub Gists from Jupyter notebooks
pull_commit_message:
Add Mozilla Code of Conduct file

Fixes #72.

_(Message COC002)_

pulltitle: Fix #46: Add loading controls to tree page.
pullsbody:
This adds the loading-related buttons to the tree page, but otherwise is 
the same code and functionality.

It reorganizes the code into a notebook extension, a tree extension (the
file browser page), and code that is common between the two.

Since extension files have been added, this requires uninstalling and
reinstalling the notebook extensions (as per our README.md).

pulltitle: Fix #60: Fix download notebook to server.
pullsbody:
Since 4.3.0, Jupyter requires that a xsrf token is passed with all requests
to the server.

This uses Jupyter's utils.ajax API call to make the request which is a thin
wrapper around jquery.ajax that handles the xsrf authentication.

Downside is that this change requires a minimum version of Jupyter notebook
of 4.3.1
pull_repo_desc: Create, list, and load GitHub Gists from Jupyter notebooks
pull_commit_message:
Fix #60: Fix download notebook to server.

Since 4.3.0, Jupyter requires that a xsrf token is passed with all requests
to the server.

This uses Jupyter's utils.ajax API call to make the request which is a thin
wrapper around jquery.ajax that handles the xsrf authentication.

Downside is that this change requires a minimum version of Jupyter notebook
of 4.3.1

pulltitle: Attempt to fix Travis CI config
pullsbody:
Adds Python 3.6, drops Python 3.3

Fixes version conflict around flake8

Adds tornado (which wasn't getting installed automatically into pypy)

This also uses a different Travis CI VM configuration for each Python version, rather than using the same one and having tox pick different versions.  It seems recent Travis VMs (such as python-3.6) don't have multiple Python versions installed anymore.
pull_repo_desc: Create, list, and load GitHub Gists from Jupyter notebooks

pulltitle: Fix #53, Fix #56: Don't corrupt notebook.json when no oauth_client_id
pullsbody:
When there is no `c.NotebookGist.oauth_client_id` in jupyter_notebook_config.py,
`self.config.NotebookGist.oauth_client_id` is a lazy value, which can't be
serialized to JSON.  This crashes the writing of `notebook.json` by Jupyter,
and corrupts the `notebook.json` file.  This fix makes sure that value is a
string, otherwise it just sets it to `None`.  When `None`, the frontend will
helpfully warn (as it always has) that the user hasn't set up their oauth ids.

r? @jezdez

Fix #53, Fix #56: Don't corrupt notebook.json when no oauth_client_id

When there is no `c.NotebookGist.oauth_client_id` in jupyter_notebook_config.py,
`self.config.NotebookGist.oauth_client_id` is a lazy value, which can't be
serialized to JSON.  This crashes the writing of `notebook.json` by Jupyter,
and corrupts the `notebook.json` file.  This fix makes sure that value is a
string, otherwise it just sets it to `None`.  When `None`, the frontend will
helpfully warn (as it always has) that the user hasn't set up their oauth ids.

pullsbody:
This allows for easier access and manipulatio and optional passing of
parameters on the command line instead of config file.

Additionally we can update the frontend settings with the client id
automatically instead of having to do this manually in the config file.

This is basically a replacement for #47, please let me know what you think.

pull_commit_message: Fix isort error

pullsbody:
This requires to use the official jupyter CLI tool to enable the extension
after pip-installing it instead of using a custom solution.

It enables the option to install from whl files and fixes a threadsafety
issue with the Tornado handler.

See the commits for more details.

pull_commit_message:
Refactor package to fit current Python packaging and Jupyter best practices.

- Removed auto-configuration from setup.py
- Use Jupyter discovery endpoints for use of nbextension and serverextension subcommands
- Enabled universal building wheel
- Added Tox config and simplified Travis config
- Added test coverage reporting
- Updated README
- Added gitignore file
- Fixed code style to match PEP8 and PEP257 better

pullsbody:
The notebook path is a `unicode` rather than a `str`. This is on the following setup:
- Ubuntu 15.10 x64
- Python 2.7.10
- Jupyter 4.0.6

Without this patch, exporting fails with `ERROR: Problem with notebook file name`. With it, it works fine.

pulltitle: Load users gists (Phase 1 - public gists only)
pullsbody:
Currently, a user can click a button and input their GitHub username into a prompt. Their public gists containing .ipynb files will then be listed. Each gist has a button that, when clicked, will open the notebook in a new window. 

I am still trying to think of a way to authorize to GitHub without having to redirect, so this isn't merge ready yet. But any feedback is welcome!

pull_commit_message: edits to make PEP8 compliant

pullsbody:
I can now install using pip by opening a shell at the top level of the project directory, and typing 'pip install .' to tell pip to install whatever's in the current directory.

I've tested wiping my entire jupyter/ipython installation, then running the single command 'pip install .' and this grabs the dependencies as expected before installing our extension.

I have not yet tested installing via the remote repo, but I'll can test that once the pull request gets merged. I expected it to work the same as installing from a local directory.

I changed the readme to specify that (at least to the end user installing our extension), manually copying/symlinking gist.js is no longer necessary.

If you're testing out pip installs, to "uninstall" our extension after doing a pip install, wipe the following directories:

<PYTHON_INSTALL_DIRECTORY>/Lib/site-packages/jupyter-notebook-gist
<PYTHON_INSTALL_DIRECTORY>/Lib/site-packages/jupyter-notebook-gist-0.0.0-py3.5.egg-info
<JUPYTER_USER_DIRECTORY>/nbextensions/gist.js (for me, the full path to this was C:/Users/Lewis/AppData/Roaming/jupyter/nbextensions/gist.js)

There is a 'pip uninstall' command that exists, and we might want to add support for this in the future. Granted, it doesn't look like Jupyter Notebook uninstalls properly when I run this, so I don't know how much people actually expect that command to work. Implementing seems to be considered optional.

There does exists a way to do a pip install that creates symlinks for development use instead of actually copying files. This would let us run 'pip install -e .' once, then never again while we're developing, and the symlink makes sure we're always running the latest version. I haven't played around with this yet. The old method of manually copying gist.js and setting the config settings to point to the right directories should still work for now.

Having a few people test this on different OSs and different versions of python would be good. If you'd like to test, I'd recommend wiping anything in your .jupyter/.ipython config directories that you set up for this extension (other than the github client id/secret, as shown in the new readme). Also wipe the copy of gist.js you copied manually for development. After doing this, run the notebook to make sure the extension does not appear, then do the pip install and confirm that is does.

Please review and let me know of any suggestions/comments/questions!
pull_repo_desc: Create, list, and load GitHub Gists from Jupyter notebooks
pull_commit_message: Project can now be installed via 'pip install jupyter-notebook-gist'

I can now install using pip by opening a shell at the top level of the project directory, and typing 'pip install .' to tell pip to install whatever's in the current directory.

I've tested wiping my entire jupyter/ipython installation, then running the single command 'pip install .' and this grabs the dependencies as expected before installing our extension.

I have not yet tested installing via the remote repo, but I'll can test that once the pull request gets merged. I expected it to work the same as installing from a local directory.

I changed the readme to specify that (at least to the end user installing our extension), manually copying/symlinking gist.js is no longer necessary.

If you're testing out pip installs, to "uninstall" our extension after doing a pip install, wipe the following directories:

<PYTHON_INSTALL_DIRECTORY>/Lib/site-packages/jupyter-notebook-gist
<PYTHON_INSTALL_DIRECTORY>/Lib/site-packages/jupyter-notebook-gist-0.0.0-py3.5.egg-info
<JUPYTER_USER_DIRECTORY>/nbextensions/gist.js (for me, the full path to this was C:/Users/Lewis/AppData/Roaming/jupyter/nbextensions/gist.js)

There is a 'pip uninstall' command that exists, and we might want to add support for this in the future. Granted, it doesn't look like Jupyter Notebook uninstalls properly when I run this, so I don't know how much people actually expect that command to work. Implementing seems to be considered optional.

There does exists a way to do a pip install that creates symlinks for development use instead of actually copying files. This would let us run 'pip install -e .' once, then never again while we're developing, and the symlink makes sure we're always running the latest version. I haven't played around with this yet. The old method of manually copying gist.js and setting the config settings to point to the right directories should still work for now.

Having a few people test this on different OSs and different versions of python would be good. If you'd like to test, I'd recommend wiping anything in your .jupyter/.ipython config directories that you set up for this extension (other than the github client id/secret, as shown in the new readme). Also wipe the copy of gist.js you copied manually for development. After doing this, run the notebook to make sure the extension does not appear, then do the pip install and confirm that is does.

Please review and let me know of any suggestions/comments/questions!

pullsbody:
Supports pasting in a Gist URL ([example](https://gist.github.com/yeah568/4e9e6e17ff55ca67afb1)) or a direct link to a .ipynb file ([example](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/yeah568/4e9e6e17ff55ca67afb1/raw/6ab5e44679a9f84bc81ae8a774ca0a857a1d891c/f.ipynb)).

This code parses the URL, sends the appropriate info to the server, which then downloads the file into the current working directory, and sends a filename back to the front end to open. Will currently break somewhat if using a raw .ipynb URL where the filename contains certain symbols.

pulltitle: Creating a new revision for existing gists
pullsbody:
When exporting a notebook to GitHub gists, it will now:
1) Save as a new gist if no other gists exist with the notebook files
2) Create a new revision of an existing gist if possible
3) Error if there are multiple gists with the same files.
